text: Do you know why popular post with {{TAGsector}} doesn’t work ?
try doing something like thia5t on line
on line 5
::{{ TAGsector|pprint }}::
maybe there is a space you need to trim or something else in there

We fully understand. These sites were built this way prior to HubDB being released.

The one hitch that we have with HubDB that might cause us to use a blog over it currently is that there's no way to create a custom UI for entering the content.

What you guys did with HubDB is a terrific start, the issue though that we have is say we have a lot of data to store, requiring (just throwing out a number) 15+ columns. Right now the editing experience is pretty poor and confusing for the marketing folks.

*For developers the table format is perfect, we just want to be able to make the fields editable in a different interface.*

For example if you have 15+ columns and you're trying to say enter data on a new product, that's a lot of stuff all in one column. it also separates the data from it's appearance in the site which Marketers really like to be able to see.

We fully realize using a blog was not the greatest thing we could do but it avoided the need to have outside databases and made the editing experience more seamless for the people managing the site. Basically we used the tools we had, to give editors the best experience we could with what we have.
anyone ever do an email template  with a HubSpot account that had multiple locations — and if so how did you bring in the address from the different locations

Thanks for your answer
I tried 
{{ blog_recent_topic_posts(‘default’, ‘{{TAGsector|pprint}}’, 5) }} but stlil unsuccessful
<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/email-user-guide-v2/how-to-set-up-your-email-footer-information#5-multiple-email-footers-enterprise-only>
I should have mentioned <@U38EZFVFE> I’m doing this in a coded template
What I’m trying to get you to do is print out TAGsector — not inside the blog_recent_topic_posts
that way you can see what is actually printing for teh variable
<h1>::{{ TAGsector|pprint }}::</h1>
I do that all teh time when creating variable to make sure I know what their actual value is
OK Thanks I will try :slightly_smiling_face:

Yeah, you have to have the can spam stuff anyways. But if you are using enterprise edition you can put all of your locations in the email footer and when you create the email it will ask you what footer info to use.

My variable seems to be good
::defense-securite::
and I want to set *defense-securite* as topic in blog_recent_topic_posts

DONE 
No bracket or quotes
just
{{ blog_recent_topic_posts(‘default’, TAGsector, 5) }}
Thanks for your time and answers :slightly_smiling_face:
As always
all that makes sense!
